name: 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid
Reason: 3,5-Bis(trifluoromethyl)phenylacetic acid has a melting point that is influenced by the functional groups in the molecule relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The introduction of two phenyl groups contributes to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C per group, totaling +40°C. The trifluoromethyl group introduces a significant dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +30°C. The carboxy group introduces a hydroxyl group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +10°C.
